IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
This incident was recorded on body mounted audio and visual equipment.
     
SCENE PROCESSING:
Photos of damage to the vehicle was conducted as well as interviews of the victim. The possible crime scene was searched for evidence and casings from the shooting.

PHYSICAL EVIDENCE: 

A single bullet fragment was collected from the victim’s vehicle and taken by CED Cpl. Null.
NARATIVE:
      
On 1/6/2023, at approximately 0240 hours, I, Trooper Wynne #6594, was on routine patrol operating in my marked Maryland State Police patrol vehicle, when I was called to respond to 5500 Chemical Road Baltimore MD for a shooting. While responding I became aware of a vehicle that was stopped on the right shoulder at eastbound I-695 in the area of Camp Meade Rd. The vehicle appeared to be parked partially on the right shoulder. It appeared to be a silver four-door passenger car with an amber light bar on the top with flags on the side of the roof. None of these lights were activated however the brake lights were illuminated. I informed the MSP Glen Burnie Barrack to start SHA CHART to check on this vehicle.
At 0309 hours I arrived on scene with the victim vehicle in the shooting. The vehicle was a white Freightliner Tractor bearing CT registration 56076A, pulling a fifty-three foot Great Dane Trailer, bearing ME registration TLR 24-7535E. I identified the driver and victim as Thomas E Fusiek W/M DOB 9/15/1953 by his Connecticut Driver’s License. Fusiek stated that he had observed a white car with flags and a “blue light” stopped on the left side of the road as he was driving eastbound on I-695. Fusiek wasn’t exactly sure of the location but he said he was prior to the drawbridge. Fusiek stated the vehicle pulled out and passed him. He said he then heard a series of pops and saw some orange flashes. The suspect vehicle then accelerated until it was alongside a truck in front of him. Fusiek described the other truck as possibly a double, pulling a trailer with a “big company” logo, possibly Old Dominion.
Fusiek stated that he then saw a rapid series of orange flashes and that he now realized that he and the other truck were being shot at. Fusiek stated the suspect vehicle then took an exit which allowed the suspect to pass over the highway to the left. I told him that the only exit in the area that would allow him to do that would be eastbound I-695, the ramp to Rt. 648. The other truck continued on, apparently not taking notice of the incident.
Having heard this description of the suspect vehicle I determined that the vehicle that I had passed had a possibility of being the suspect. I asked Anne Arundel County Police to check the area. They did so however were unable to locate that vehicle.
I observed the damage to Fusiek’s truck. There was an obvious bullet hole low on the windshield directly in front of the passenger seat. There were shards of glass on the passenger seat. Amongst the shards of glass was a large bullet fragment. I was able to locate two other impact points on the front of the tractor. One was low on the bumper towards the driver’s side and the third was through the grill on the passenger side. The frame of the truck deflected these other rounds. Other than the hole in the windshield the tractor was in working order.
I waited for the MSP Criminal Enforcement Division investigator to arrive. Cpl. Null #6149 responded to the scene. Cpl. Null conducted his own interview of Fusiek. I assisted Cpl. Null in gathering information from a nearby Old Dominion Frieght yard. We then searched the left side of I-695 from MD-295 untill Rt. 648 searching for shell casings or other evidence with negative results.
I respectfully request this case be transferred to CED
            
All events occurred in Anne Arundel County and Baltimore City, MD

Victim:
  • Fusiek, Thomas
    • W/M DOB: 09/15/1953
Suspect:
  • Unknown
Witness:
  • Due to the nature of the incident no witness information was collected. 
Neighborhood Check:
  • 6971 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 6975 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 6915 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 6946 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 6931 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 6898 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 6921 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 463 N Camp Meade Rd
  • 458 N Camp Meade Rd
Evidence:
  • Photographs attached to this report.
  • 1 projectile fragment recovered from Freightliner
Scene Processing:
  • Investigators conducted an interview with the victim. Investigators recovered a projectile from the victim vehicle and photographed the vehicle. Investigators attempted to identify an additional victim through interviews and License Plate Readers. Investigators walked the scene of the crime in an attempt to locate additional evidence. Investigators conducted a neighborhood check of the surrounding area and retrieved video surveillance which did not provide any additional leads at this time. Investigators obtained 9-1-1 recordings from Baltimore City Police Department. 
Additional Information:
  • 2013 Freightliner Truck Tractor
    • CT 56076A
    • Flemings Transportation Inc.
Narrative:
    On Friday, January 6, 2023, at approximately 0235 hours, Trooper First Class Wynne, of the Maryland State Police Glen Burnie Barrack, responded to the area of 5500 Chemical Road, Baltimore MD for the report of a shooting. TFC Wynne contacted the complainant / victim identified as Fusiek, Thomas (W/M DOB: 09/15/1953) and obtained initial information. Fusiek stated that he was traveling East on I695 in the area of what he believed to be Rt 10 when he saw a white vehicle sitting on the side of the road. Fusiek advised the vehicle pulled onto 695 in front of him at which time he heard several sounds what he thought were gunshots. The suspect vehicle then sped up and Fusiek advised he observed what he believed to be several muzzle flashes coming from the passenger side of the suspect vehicle. Fusiek believes the suspect was firing rounds at another Old Dominion tractor trailer that was traveling in the area. The suspect vehicle exited the highway. Fusiek described the suspect vehicle as a white passenger car with a flag and blue light at the top. When Fusiek arrived at his location he observed a hole in his windshield and found a bullet on his front passenger seat. At that time, the Glen Burnie Barrack contacted the Criminal Enforcement Division and I, Cpl Null 6149 of the Maryland State Police Criminal Enforcement Division Central South Region, responded to the scene.

    Upon my arrival, I made contact with TFC Wynne who provided a summary of events. I then requested to interview Fusiek, who agreed to be interview. I interviewed Fusiek in the front seat of my assigned agency vehicle and conducted a recorded interview. During the interview, I determined Fusiek entered 695 from I-95 south and traveled on 695 to Quarantine Rd. While on 695, Fusiek advised he saw a white vehicle, with what he described as flags and a blue light on the roof, parked off the left side of the roadway with the front of the vehicle further in the shoulder than the rear end. Shortly after Fusiek passed this vehicle, he observed the vehicle to pass him on the left in lane one (the left lane). As the vehicle passed his truck he heard several gunshots. The suspect vehicle passed his truck and approached a second truck and trailer, which Fusiek believed to be an Old Dominion trailer. As the suspect vehicle was passing the Old Dominion Truck, Fusiek observed what he described as muzzle flashes and heard numerous rapid gunshots. Fusiek described his proximity to this incident as approximately 10 trailers. Fusiek then stated the suspect vehicle passed the Old Dominion truck, and he lost sight of the vehicle for a short time before observing the vehicle on an overpass crossing 695. Fusiek continued on 695 as well as the Old Dominion truck. Fusiek states he believes the Old Dominion trailer must have been struck because the driver did not slow or stop. When Fusiek arrived at his destination, he began to smell what he believed to be gunpowder and then noticed his windshield was damaged. When asked Fusiek advised he believed the incident occurred between 0030 hours and 0130 hours. I reviewed a map with Fusiek and determined he observed the suspect vehicle on the Baltimore Annapolis Blvd overpass. Furthermore, Fuseik advised his vehicle is equipped with a dashcam that should activate when the truck powers on and provided a point of contact with his company to follow up with.

    After my interview with Fuseik, TFC Wynne provided me with the projectile he recovered from Fusiek's vehicle. I photographed the vehicle and searched the cab of the truck for any additional evidence. I noted the projectile entered lower passenger side of the windshield and came to rest on the passenger seat. Additionally, while documenting the truck I noted what appeared to be two additional projectile impacts. One on the driver side bumper area, and a second through the grill on the passenger side. No other damage was observed throughout the vehicle. 

    Based on the statements of Fuseik, TFC Wynne and I responded to 2301 Hawkins Point Rd, Curtis Bay MD, 21226 - Old Dominion Service Center. Upon my arrival I made contact with Jeff Haselbarth - Operations Manager. During my contact with Haselbarth, he advised at that time of night the driver would likely be a Line Haul Driver and would not utilize his facility. Haselbarth stated the last truck to utilize his faculty would be in before midnight and the first trucks to leave would be around 0400 hours. Additionally, Haselbarth contacted his company's safe department who stated no reports of damaged trailers have been reported. On January 16, 2023, I followed up with Old Dominion and learned there was still no report of damaged trailers. 

    After leaving Old Dominion, TFC Wynne and I responded to 695 in the area of 295. TFC Wynne with the assistance of State Highway Administration closed lane 1 while I walked the roadway attempting to locate any evidence. A ground search between 295 and Baltimore was conducted in lane 1 and the shoulder and I did not recover any items of evidentiary value. 

    Next, I conducted a neighborhood check on Baltimore Annapolis Blvd. I checked Lynn Hill Apartments located on Hillview Dr. A check of the apartment complex revealed no vehicle matching the description. Furthermore, I noted several businesses that may have video surveillance capturing Baltimore Annapolis Blvd. 

    At that time, I responded to the Maryland State Police Glen Burnie Barrack and processed the projectile per MSP policy to be submitted to the Maryland State Police Forensic Science Division Laboratory at a later date for analysis and to be entered into National Integrated Ballistic Information Network (NIBIN).


    I then contacted Flemings Transportation Inc. via phone and inquired about Fusiek's dashcam. Flemings Transportation Inc. advised the camera was not uploading over the air, and they were going to attempt to download the camera upon return of the truck. I contacted Flemings Transportation Inc. at a later date and learned the camera was not functional at the time of the incident. 

    On January 6, 2023, myself and other Central South Investigators responded to multiple business to follow up with surveillance footage. The following is the results of those neighborhood checks. 
  • 6971 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • Exxon
      • No surveillance footage available
  • 6975 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • Mikes Auto Repair
      • Not equipped with surveillance cameras
  • 6915 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • Holden Truck Repair Inc
      • Not equipped with surveillance cameras
  • 6946 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • Private residence
      • Equipped with Ring Door Bell. Spoke with homeowner Leticia Bradshaw (B/F DOB: 03/30/1984) and reviewed footage. No suspect vehicle was captured.
  • 6931 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • Belle Grove Corp
      • No surveillance footage that captures Baltimore Annapolis Blvd. Spoke with the site superintendent Walter Swift. Swift advised that there was no scheduled oversized loads that would require follow / escort vehicles.
  • 6898 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • A-1 Auto Body
      • Reviewed several hours of surveillance that captured Baltimore Annapolis Blvd. Observed an unknown white sedan with tinted windows, but lacked flags or lights, at 0140 hours. 
  • 6921 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • Comfort Inn & Suites
      • No surveillance cameras that captured Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
  • 6899 Baltimore Annapolis Blvd
    • Checker's
      • Reviewed several hours of video surveillance that captured Belle Grove Road. No vehicles were observed matching the suspect vehicle.
  • 463 N Camp Meade Rd
    • Shell
      • Reviewed several hours of video surveillance that partially captured Baltimore Annapolis Blvd. No vehicles were observed matching the suspect vehicle.
  • 458 N Camp Meade Rd
    • Dunkin Donuts
      • No video surveillance that captures Baltimore Annapolis Blvd.
  • 401 Wanda Dr
    • Private residence
      • Spoke to the homeowner in reference to a Ring Doorbell. The camera does not capture any part of Baltimore Annapolis Blvd. 
    Based on Fusiek's belief an Old Dominion trailer was also targeted. I requested License Plate Reads for the Francis Scott Key Bridge in an attempt to identify the vehicle. A thorough review of these reads was unable to determine if an Old Dominion trailer utilized the Francis Scott Key Bridge.

    Furthermore, I attempted to retrieve the original 9-1-1 call from Fuseik. I learned that Baltimore City Police Department reviewed a 9-1-1 call from Fusiek at 0143 hours. Baltimore City Police Department originally responded and learned the incident occurred outside of their jurisdiction and subsequently contacted the Maryland State Police to handle the incident. 

    Based on the lack of investigative leads, I request this case suspended. If a return from NIBIN returns leads this case can be reopened. 

Case: Suspended
Corporal Z. Null 6149
